title: In praise of slowness - Carl Honore

multiple-choice.question: What is the main observation made by the author about the culture of speed?

options.label: B
options.text: That people are getting faster and more efficient.

options.label: C
options.text: That the culture of speed is ironic because people are trying to slow down quickly.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To tackle the cultural taboo against slowing down.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the idea that slower is always better.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: That people should only eat organic food.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the idea that slower is always better.

options.label: D

title: How to use expertsâ€”and when not to - Noreena Hertz

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with relying too heavily on experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Experts are not contributing enough to the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Experts are too focused on their own careers.

options.label: C
options.text: We've become addicted to their certainty and have ceded our responsibility.

options.label: D
options.text: Experts are not making enough money.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the independent decision-making parts of our brains when we listen to experts?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more active and engaged.

options.label: C
options.text: They switch off and become flatlined.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less active and less engaged.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of relying too heavily on experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more confident and self-assured.

options.label: B
options.text: We become more open-minded and democratic.

options.label: C
options.text: We become more likely to make mistakes and miss important information.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more likely to achieve our goals and succeed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with experts forming rigid camps and dominating perspectives?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to more creativity and innovation.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to more debate and discussion.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to the silencing of opposition and the ignoring of complexity and nuance.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to more collaboration and teamwork.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of experts making mistakes, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to more trust and confidence in experts.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to more skepticism and criticism of experts.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to more harm and damage to individuals and society.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to more research and development of new ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for dealing with experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Being willing to take experts on and dispense with the notion of them as modern-day apostles.

options.label: B
options.text: Being willing to dig behind experts' graphs, equations, and forecasts.

options.label: C
options.text: Being willing to challenge experts and their assumptions.

options.label: D
options.text: Being willing to blindly follow and accept experts' opinions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second strategy for dealing with experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating the space for what he calls "managed dissent".

options.label: B
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more open-minded and democratic.

options.label: C
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more confident and self-assured.

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more skeptical and critical.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third strategy for dealing with experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Democratizing expertise and embracing the expertise within companies and organizations.

options.label: B
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more focused on their own careers.

options.label: C
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more confident and self-assured.

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging experts to be more skeptical and critical.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of embracing dissent and challenging experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more likely to make mistakes and miss important information.

options.label: B
options.text: We become more likely to achieve our goals and succeed.

options.label: C
options.text: We become more likely to face the world with eyes wide open and be better prepared for challenges.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more likely to blindly follow and accept experts' opinions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: We should blindly follow and accept experts' opinions.

options.label: B
options.text: We should be more confident and self-assured in our decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: We should be more open-minded and democratic in our approach to experts.

options.label: D
options.text: We should face the world with eyes wide open and be better prepared for challenges.

multiple-choice.question: C: We've become addicted to their certainty and have ceded our responsibility.
C: They switch off and become flatlined.
C: We become more likely to make mistakes and miss important information.
C: It leads to the silencing of opposition and the ignoring of complexity and nuance.
C: It leads to more harm and damage to individuals and society.
A: Being willing to take experts on and dispense with the notion of them as modern-day apostles.
A: Creating the space for what he calls "managed dissent".
A: Democratizing expertise and embracing the expertise within companies and organizations.

D: We should face the world with eyes wide open and be better prepared for challenges.

title: One is one...or is it? - Christopher Danielson

options.label: C

options.text: A dozen eggs is a box of toaster pastries.

options.label: B
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is a dozen eggs.

options.label: C
options.text: A dozen eggs is composed of composed units, and a box of toaster pastries is partitioned.

options.label: D
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is composed of partitioned units, and a dozen eggs is composed.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A slice of pizza is partitioned, and a box of toaster pastries is composed.

options.text: The number 100 is greater than the number 10.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: A fishing technique that used a spear.
